qas.question: How many groups are FETs split into?
What are the names of the groups of FETs

answers.text: junction FET (JFET) and insulated gate FET (IGFET)

qas.question: What is the common term for an IFGET?
How is a JFET different from an IGFET?

answers.text: the JFET gate forms a p–n diode with the channel

qas.question: What mode do both JFET and IGFET operate in?
What is a vacuum tube triode made from?
What controls the amount of input voltage?
How many layers of metal are in the gate of an IGFET?
What kind of FET is mass produced?

context: FETs are divided into <a0_0><b7_0>two<b7_0/><a0_0/> families: <a1_0>junction FET (JFET) and insulated gate FET (IGFET)<a1_0/>. The IGFET is more commonly known as <a2_0>a metal–oxide–semiconductor FET (MOSFET)<a2_0/>, reflecting its original construction from layers of metal (<b6_0>the gate<b6_0/>), oxide (the insulation), and <b5_0>semiconductor<b5_0/>. Unlike IGFETs, <a3_0>the JFET gate forms a p–n diode with the channel<a3_0/> which lies between the source and drain. Functionally, this makes the n-channel JFET the solid-state equivalent of the vacuum tube triode which, similarly, forms a diode between its grid and cathode. Also, <b8_0>both devices<b8_0/> operate in the <a4_0>depletion mode<a4_0/>, they both have a high input impedance, and they both conduct current under the control of an input voltage.
